1118220569898553344.text: Of course that all fell to pieces during the Depression. But Liberty Bonds - and people like Chaplin promoting them - birthed the modern investing system that most households now participate in. Like most things, happened by accident.

1118220526814732288.text: After the war that relationship between modest household and broker remained and gave rise to an investor class that for the first time expanded beyond aristocratic families.

1118220485379153920.text: So this was millions of Americans' first experience with investing. It was also their first introduction to brokers and advisors.

1118220430786035713.text: It was a big deal because until that point virtually all securities were owned by banks and very rich families. Ordinary people becoming investors was a new concept.

1118220391221276672.text: Liberty Bonds were unique in that the government for the first time asked every household, rich or poor, to invest in a marketable security.

1118220361580077058.text: The picture is Charlie Chaplin in front of the New York Stock Exchange in 1918. He's promoting Liberty Bonds to fund World War I.

He can't figure out shadows. What's the difference between a stain on a couch and a shadow on the couch?

He can't distinguish a man's face from a woman's. Try to do it with just words. It's hard.

1112462176269275136.text: Automatic recognition: He can't look at a picture of a cat and know it's a cat. He has to look for clues -- tail, pointy ears, etc -- and put together the clues. Makes you realize how powerful our brains are that can do it automatically.

1112462096535560192.text: He's blown away by 2D images. He can't understand why you can't feel the details in a picture. Everything in his life before was 3D.

1112461711045332992.text: He's very smart -- CEO of a tech company. But learning to read at age 46, by the time he gets to the third letter in a word he forgets what the first two letters were and has to start over.
